user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_traverse:
```c
int lfs_fs_traverse(lfs_t *lfs, int (*cb)(void *, lfs_block_t), void *data) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_fs_traverse(%p, %p, %p)",
            (void*)lfs, (void*)(uintptr_t)cb, data);

    err = lfs_fs_traverse_(lfs, cb, data, true);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_fs_traverse -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment calls LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg), which is not a standard <string.h> function. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 specifically concerns use of string.h functions (memcpy, strcpy, memset, etc.). This line does not invoke any of those functions, so it does not by itself cause a Rule 21.17 breach. (Note: if the LFS_LOCK macro/function expands to or calls a string.h routine that misuses pointer bounds, that expansion would need separate review.)
